author: Bang Ong
title: Celebrate joy and prosperity with these 9 classic Lunar New Year movies
text: Celebrate joy and prosperity with these 9 classic Lunar New Year movies Usher in the Year of the Rooster with these films 28 January 2017 / 11:35MYT by Bang Ong A fairly recent phenomenon, the tradition of Lunar New Year movies is probably less than half a century old, and very likely borne out of that keen Chinese radar for buckets of money - red packet money, that is. These mostly comedic celebration films also provide some relief from the typically heavier Oscar fare that plagues the earlier months of the year, so they stand a good chance of doing quite well at the box office regardless of their quality. So this year we’ve put together a list of nine (a lucky number) classic lunar new year films that have, and will undoubtedly still exponentially multiply the joy, laughter and prosperity of your Lunar New Year break. We’ve excluded Stephen Chow’s movies because we’ve got a whole other article dedicated to him right here . Gong Xi Fa Cai! Embedded video Fat Choi Spirit This Andy Lau mahjong movie was almost an instant classic upon its release, and it's not hard to see why - mahjong is to Chinese New Year what Turkey is to Thanksgiving. There have been other mahjong movies in its wake, but none have managed to so vividly capture the imagination of audiences since. Nothing will rev up your mahjong glands more than watching this movie. Many mahjong players actually style their gaming habits based on the advice doled out in the film - whether or not it actually improves their chances is anyone’s guess. Embedded video God of Gamblers The God of Gamblers is not just the faceless deity to which all Chinese quietly beseech during their “friendly” new year card games, nor is it just the venerable Chow Yun Fat. It is the longest running gambling film franchise in all of Hong Kong cinema, and that's not even including its various spinoffs. Although it was not initially intended as a CNY film, the series (recently rebranded as “From Vegas To Macau”) eventually started to coincide with the CNY holidays and adopted a more light-hearted and celebratory tone. The most effective advertising for casinos to Chinese people ever. Embedded video Who Am I Chinese New Year is not just all about gambling. In his heyday, several of Jackie Chan’s action comedies were released during this period, and “Who Am I” happens to be one of the more successful ones. Playing an agent who has lost his memory, Jackie Chan finds himself globetrotting in order to solve the mystery of his identity. The movie is rife with incredible stunts, including one in which he almost just casually slides down the side of a very steep and very tall building - a stunt that found its way into Tom Cruise’s repertoire in Mission Impossible 3. Way to go Jackie!
